content.description: Stand start the slick slab above the chasm/ pit. Straight up is harder, going left is easier.Can't remember if we sat-start.
content.protection: 3 pads. The slab is slick. Stuff a pad in the hole then cover it up.

content.description: Sit start the overhanging arete with a left hand pinch and a right hand sloping undercling on the overhang. Find some feet and pull on with difficulty. Either dyno up right hand to a blind jug or smack up the arete lefty then dyno.
content.protection: 2 pads. landing is good but tapered towards the block, almost like an antlion's cone shaped sand trap.
content.location: This problem is found on the boulder found in the depression, the long elongated block 20 yards past the Bolted Boulder. This overhanging arete is on the left side.

content.description: Sit start the right arete on a nice hold, move up and left with a few tricky moves, then continue left along the series of jugs staying low. Traverse all the way left to the left arete using a series of awesome horizontal holds and jugs and then finish up the arete. This problem links "Sandshrew" all the way into "Sand Attack". It is a great traverse and an awesome warm up. One can top out ar any point making the full thing a bit forced.
content.protection: 2 pads. The traverse is lowball. A pad at the start and at the end will do.
content.location: This problem traverses the entire uphill face from right to left.

content.description: Sit start with a glassy incut on the lip. pull on and head left on slippery holds until you can reach a bucket then top out.
content.location: This problem is further down the hill from the Bolted Boulder. It is on the smaller of the two boulders.

content.description: Sit start with both hands on a good hold. Find some feet and make a hard move up to a jug, once on the jug, figure out how to get the feet up and take it to the top of the block.
content.location: This problem is found on the long boulder in the depression. The same boulder as "Trapinch" and "Sandshrew" and "Fissure".

content.description: Sit start the cool quartz blob-like rail in the middle of the long uphill face. Pull on with some awkward feet and thrutch up to a jug, then topout with ease. Lowball, but the starting hold is too cool not to be a climb.
content.location: Middle of the long face. To the left of "Fissure" and "Sandshrew".

content.description: Sit start the slabby right arete. Figure it out and go straight up.
content.location: This problem is on the right side of the roadside face of the long boulder.The right hand is on the same arete that "Trapinch" uses for its left-hand starting hold.

content.description: Hands-free slabs get their own grading system.Do it in the sneakers or be lame and use the climbing shoes. No knees, no elbows. A head dab might be kosher.Stand start the mellow slab and head up and left or go right. Right may be harder.
content.protection: 2-3 pads. Landing isn't perfect and it is a decent height.
content.location: This slab is found facing the Magnitude Boulder. It is to the right of "Sandshrew" and left of "Wooper". The wall has nice features.

content.description: Sit start with a sloping left hand undercling and a crimp sidepull on the arete. Find some feet and make a hard deadpoint up to a flat sloping rail then move up to improving holds.
content.location: This problem is on the overhang just left of "Sandshrew". The right hand sidepull crimp is about a foot to the left of Sandshrew's starting hold.One may need to stack a pad to comfortably sit start the problem.

content.description: Squat or stand start the slopey technical slab next to the big hole in the ground.A sit start from the right was done into this adding a grade or so.
content.location: This problem is found on the roadside face of the boulder. It is a few feet left of the right arete.

content.description: This is a long boulder found in a large depression in the hillside. It lies between the Magnitude Boulder and the Bolted Boulder. It has a few powerful overhanging problems, some great jug hauls and some techy slabs that face the road, that have been climbed but not named.
